{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} '''The list of Apple codenames''' covers the [[code name|codenames]] given to products by [[Apple Inc.]] during development. The codenames are often used internally only, normally to maintain secrecy of the project. Occasionally a codename may become the released product's name. Most of Apple's codenames from the 1980s and 1990s are provided by the book ''Apple Confidential 2.0''.<ref name="Apple Confidential">{{cite book |last= Linzmayer |first= Owen |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mXnw5tM8QRwC |page= 45 |title= Apple Confidential 2.0: The Definitive History of the World's Most Colorful Company |publisher= [[No Starch Press]] |date= 2004 |isbn= 1-59327-010-0 |df= mdy-all |access-date= 2019-03-05 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140227175423/http://books.google.com/books?id=mXnw5tM8QRwC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q=%22code%20names%20uncovered%22&f=false |archive-date= 2014-02-27 |url-status= live }}</ref>
==Accessories== * AirTags, a [[Tile (company)|Tile-like]] personal item tracking hardware & app - ''AirTags'', ''Apple Tags'', ''B389''<ref name="Rambo">{{cite web |last1=Rambo |first1=Guilherme |title=Apple revamping Find My Friends & Find My iPhone in unified app, developing Tile-like personal item tracking |url=https://9to5mac.com/2019/04/17/find-my-iphone-revamp/ |accessdate=25 September 2019 |date=2019-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first1=Pururaj Dutta |title=Exclusive: AirTags confirmed in a new Apple Support Video! |url=https://appleosophy.com/2020/04/02/airtags-confirmed-in-a-new-apple-support-video/ |website=Appleosophy |date=2 April 2020}}</ref> * [[AirPods]] (1st Generation) - ''B188'' * [[AirPods]] (2nd Generation) - ''B288'' *[[AirPods Pro]] - ''B298'' <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2019/10/02/new-in-ear-airpods-with-noise-cancelling-found-in-ios-13-2-beta/|title=New in-ear AirPods with noise cancellation found in iOS 13.2 beta|last=Rambo|first=Guilherme|date=2019-10-02|website=9to5Mac|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-03}}</ref> * AirPods Studio (Rumored over-ear wireless headphone) - ''B515 ''<ref>{{Cite web|title=Apple's over-ear headphones may be called 'AirPods Studio' & retail for $349|url=https://appleinsider.com/articles/20/05/09/apples-over-ear-headphones-may-be-called-airpods-studio|website=AppleInsider|language=en|access-date=2020-05-16}}</ref> * [[AirPort Express|AirPort Express 802.11n (5th Generation)]] - ''K31''<ref name=Hughes /> * [[Apple IIe Card]] for the Macintosh LC - ''Double Exposure'' * A rumored [[augmented reality]] and [[virtual reality]] device - ''T288'' * [[Disk II#3.5|Apple II 3.5" Disk Controller Card]] - ''NuMustang'' * [[Apple Color OneScanner]] 600/27 - ''Rio'' * [[Apple Color OneScanner]] 1200/30 - ''New Orleans'' * [[HomePod]] - ''B238'' * Built-in [[iSight]] (2005) - ''M33'' * External [[iSight]] (2003) - ''Q8'' * Lightning Digital AV Adapter - ''Haywire'' * [[Magic Trackpad 2]] - ''D67' <ref>{{Cite web |url= http://appldnld.apple.com/osxassets/031-72490-2016008016-5A8D07A0-631B-11E6-828B-BE3E474FE3CA/com_apple_MobileAsset_prefpanes_TrackpadMouseVideos/4c802a19960a54d112696e210da8c59e84e9f243.zip |title= 169327: Fuji Preference Panes PT TrackPad (D67, 081116, PC, ProRes, 442HQ) |date= September 27, 2016 |website= [[Apple.com]] |publisher= [[Apple Inc.]] |access-date= October 16, 2016 |format= [[Zip (file format)|ZIP]] |df= mdy-all |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161018233518/http://appldnld.apple.com/osxassets/031-72490-2016008016-5A8D07A0-631B-11E6-828B-BE3E474FE3CA/com_apple_MobileAsset_prefpanes_TrackpadMouseVideos/4c802a19960a54d112696e210da8c59e84e9f243.zip |archive-date= October 18, 2016 |url-status= live }}</ref> * [[Time Capsule (Apple)|Time Capsule]] - ==Apple Watch== * [[Apple Watch]] - ''Gizmo''<ref>{{cite web |last1=Chen |first1=Brian X. |title=Apple's New Job: Selling a Smartwatch to an Uninterested Public |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/02/technology/apples-new-job-selling-a-smartwatch-to-an-uninterested-public.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&_r=0 |website=The New York Times |date=27 February 2015}}</ref>, ''N27'' and ''N28''
==Apple-designed processors== [[Apple-designed processors]]' internal codenames are named after wind and weather patterns.<ref name="Sohail">{{cite web |last= Sohail |first= Omar |title= Apple A12 Bionic & A12X Part Numbers With CPU Codename Provided in Latest Leak – Earlier Performance Numbers Peaked at 30% Better Scores |url= https://wccftech.com/apple-a12-part-number-cpu-codename/ |website= WCCF Tech |date= May 25, 2018 |df= mdy-all |access-date= August 13, 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180813112228/https://wccftech.com/apple-a12-part-number-cpu-codename/ |archive-date= August 13, 2018 |url-status= live }}</ref>

===Mac OS System=== Mac OS System is often cited as having multiple codenames. * [[System 6|System 6.0.4 (1989)]] – ''Antares'' * [[System 6|System 6.0.5 (1990)]] – ''Big Deal'' * [[System 6|System 6.0.6]] – ''SixPack (never released due to [[AppleTalk]] bug)'' * [[System 6|System 6.0.8 (1991)]] – ''Terminator'' * [[System 7]] – ''Blue, Big Bang, M80, Pleiades'' * [[System 7|System 7.0 (1991)]] – ''Furnishings 2000'' * [[System 7|System 7.0.1 (1991)]] – ''Road Warrior, Beta Cheese'' * [[System 7|System 7.1 (1992)]] – ''Cube-E, I Tripoli'' * [[System 7|System 7.1.1 (aka System 7 Pro) (1993)]] – ''Jirocho'' * Prototype of [[Star Trek project|System 7.1 for x86 processors]] – ''Star Trek'' * [[System 7|System 7.5 (PPC) (1994)]] – ''Mozart, Capone'' * [[System 7|System 7.5.1]] – ''Danook, Thag'' * [[System 7|System 7.5.2]] – ''Marconi'' * [[System 7|System 7.5.2]] – ''Unity'' * [[System 7|System 7.5.3 Revision 2.1]] – ''Buster'' * [[System 7|System 7.5.3 Revision 2.1]] – ''Son of Buster'' * [[System 7|System 7.6]] – ''Harmony'' * [[System 7|System 7.6.1]] – ''Ides of Buster''
===Mac OS and Mac OS Server=== The codename convention for Mac OS 8, 9, and [[Mac OS X Server 1.0]] mostly follow musical terminology.

===macOS=== Public release names for macOS are named after [[landmark]]s in [[California]],<ref name="techMavericks">{{cite web |url= https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/10/os-x-mavericks/ |title= Apple Has A New, California-Based Naming Scheme For OS X, Starting With OS X Mavericks |work=[[TechCrunch]] |date= June 10, 2013 |accessdate= June 10, 2013 |last= Ha |first= Anthony |url-status= live |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170709214256/https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/10/os-x-mavericks/ |archivedate= July 9, 2017 |df= mdy-all }}</ref> however the internal codenames naming convention follows after varieties of [[apple]]s.<ref name="Ritchie OSX" /> *[[macOS Sierra|macOS Sierra 10.12]] – ''Fuji'' *[[macOS High Sierra|macOS High Sierra 10.13]] – ''Lobo''<ref name="Ritchie OSX" /> *[[macOS Mojave|macOS Mojave 10.14]] – ''Liberty''<ref name="Ritchie OSX">{{cite web |last= Ritchie |first= Rene |authorlink= Rene Ritchie |title= macOS and OS X version code-names |url= https://www.imore.com/macos-version-code-names |website= [[iMore]] |date= August 30, 2017 |accessdate= March 4, 2019 |df= mdy-all |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190402194401/https://www.imore.com/macos-version-code-names |archive-date= April 2, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref> *[[macOS Catalina|macOS Catalina 10.15]] – ''Jazz''<ref>/usr/standalone/i386/SecureBoot.bundle/Contents/Resources/BuildManifest.plist <key>BuildTrain</key> <string>macOSJazz</string></ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.macworld.co.uk/feature/mac/os-x-macos-versions-3662757/ |title=Complete list of Mac OS X & macOS versions: first to the latest macOS |first=Lewis |last=Painter |date=January 13, 2020 |magazine=Macworld (UK) |access-date=April 15, 2020}}</ref>
